title: Part 5: India’s Bail Jurisprudence-Need for Urgent & Comprehensive Revamp
text:
Background of the Indian Law Commission’s 268th Report (2017)

18. The Department of Legal Affairs, Ministry of Law and Justice, asked the Law Commission of India in 2015, to examine the need for a Bail Act in India. The letter attached with the 268th report of the Law Commission, headed by Justice B S Chauhan, reflects the fact that during a meeting of the Advisory Council for Justice Delivery and Law Reforms held in 2016, it was decided that there was no need of a separate and independent Bail Act. Rather, it was observed that amendments to existing laws statutes can be suggested.

19. The Commission started working on the subject from March 2016. After a preliminary study, it called for a consultation in which it interacted and heard the views of Police Officers from a number of states in November 2016. In the next step, the Commission interacted with a cross-section of the Judicial Officers in January 2017 and heard views on the subject. During the study, the Commission also consulted and interacted with the Director General of Prosecution of all the states. After a study of 15 months with comprehensive consultations from a number of stakeholders, the Law Commission published Report No. 268, titled “Amendments to Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 – Provisions Relating to Bail” 16 . The 131-page report was shared with the Ministry of Law and Justice on 23 May 2017 and then brought into the public domain.’

20. The report consists of twelve chapters, of which the final two chapters (“XI is titled Recommendations’ and ‘XII titled Conclusion”) are the most important ones. The first ten chapters consist of the introductory part, legalities of bail jurisprudence and existing concepts of provisions on bail existing in India and around the world.

21. The Commission also shared a copy of the draft Criminal Law Amendment Bill, 2017 and consequently the Criminal Law (Amendment) Bill, 2018 has derived a number of ideas and provisions from the draft bill put forward by the Commission
